author: Nicola Harley
title: BBC editor 'breached impartiality' over Jeremy Corbyn, report reveals
text:
BBC editor 'breached impartiality' over Jeremy Corbyn, report reveals BBC accused of impartiality over Jeremy Corbyn interview. Credit: PA/PA Nicola Harley 7 January 2017 â€¢ 1:15pm 
T he BBC's political editor, Laura Kuenssberg, has been accused of breaching impartiality guidelines in a draft report over her dispatch on Jeremy Corbyn's shoot-to-kill policy. 
A leaked copy of the BBC Trust's draft report into her piece for News at Six said that there had been a "failure of impartiality". 
Her report had focused on the Labour leader's views on shoot-to-kill after the terrorist attacks in Paris in November 2015. BBC political editor Laura Kuenssberg is accused of impartiality over her report on Jeremy Corbyn's shoot-to-kill policy in 2015. Credit: Paul Grover/Paul Grover 
A viewer complained that the clip was misleading because Mr Corbyn had been asked if he would order the police or military to shoot to kill on Britain's streets without any reference to the Paris attacks. 
A prerecorded interview showed the Labour leader responding: "I'm not happy with a shoot-to-kill policy in general. I think that is quite dangerous and I think can often be counterproductive." 
The BBC Trust's editorial standards committee said that Mr Corbyn had not been specifically asked about a hostage incident, such as the Bataclan theatre siege in Paris, in which 89 people were killed in relation t the question. 
In its initial findings the regulator, which has not interviewed Ms Kuenssberg, concluded: "There was a significant difference between what Mr Corbyn said and what the report inferred. This led to a failure of due accuracy." A memorial outside the Bataclan in Paris following the 2015 terror attack. Credit: Guilhem Baker/Guilhem Baker 
I t added: "Trustees considered that the effect of the failures to observe due accuracy had, on this occasion, also resulted in a failure of impartiality." 
The Trust, which accepted there was "no evidence of any intent to deceive or distort", has agreed to reconsider the case and the BBC is to put forward evidence in its defence. 
A BBC spokesman said: "BBC News does not accept the assertions made and the complaint has been rejected on four separate occasions already. 
"The Trust has not published a finding regarding this appeal and BBC News has further evidence it is still to present this month before that happens."
